comments.body:
If you're using an IP, how do you validate the certificate?

Relatedly, do you validate the hostname *at all*?
Some testing later: no, the `ssl.get_server_certificate` does not validate the hostname, only the certificate signature. You should probably note this in the docs.

We are not doing any kind of validation in this module (other than the signature by passing in ca_file). This is strictly for getting a certificate from a port for inspection. What if we made the module description something like:

Makes a secure connection and returns information about the presented certificate optionally validating the certs signature
I think you can add something along the lines of "only validates the certificate itself, does not validate if the certificate is valid for the supplied host" to the `ca_certs` setting.

Sorry for the delay, all set:
```
- ca_certs
        A PEM file containing a list of root certificates; if present, the cert will be validated against these root certs.
        Note that this only validates the certificate is signed by the chain; not that the cert is valid for the host presenting it.
        [Default: (null)]
```

@thomwiggers 

> If you're using an IP, how do you validate the certificate?

You can specify subjectAltName to an IP adress and hence have a valid certificate bound to an IP[1] and not the hostname. However I don't think this is widely used. This is if I understood the inital comment, if not please dicard my answer.

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280#section-4.2.1.6

comments.body:
Will return incomplete subject if duplicate OIDs in component names.
`CN=testcertificates.com, OU=Admin, OU=Accounting`

Whoops, hit "go" without finishing my comment.

Anyways, that would result in a dict that just had 
CN: testcertificates.com
OU: Accounting

And if crypto + pyopenssl return subject components in different orders (they may not, I hope they don't, but I've never tested it and I've seen that happen in other languages twice) the output will be different between backends.

BTW: when the review hasn't been finished, you can still edit the messages without anyone noticing :)

I would assume that they both return them in the order they show up in the certificate. I guess we have to look at their implementation to be on the safe side.

Oh, didn't realize that about the comments.

It's a not-uncommon issue that the "friendly" display order for a subject DN is the inverse order of the canonical encoding - I've run into multiple applications and hardware that dump things out "reversed" from each other, including a hardware gateway that once changed the ordering within the same major version as a "bugfix".

It's probably not something worth a deep-dive for an informational module.
Same as concern with the pyopenssl, drops duplicate components.
Meant to leave immediately previous comment here - cryptography code drops duplicate components as well.

Technically subject components need to be ordered, so a dict wouldn't work well.

However, I get the impression that the purpose of this module is informative rather than actionable (particularly since it doesn't return thumbprint/public key/etc), in which case I would agree that it doesn't matter if the results are ordered, since it would be an abuse of this module in the first place to be _doing things_ based on subject DN, when it comes to certificate validation/chain building/etc.

True indeed. Probably the best solution would be to return a list of `(type, value)` pairs. Not very handy to work with, though :)

My assumption is also that the result of this module (except the certificate itself) is mostly informational: one can quickly get some information from it without processing the certificate further. Like check whether the common name is `My Company` instead of `Whatever Else`.
